text:
Sawaddee ka if you've been to Thailand you 
may have seen something like this sitting

on the table at the restaurant you're going 
to this is what I like to call the standard

Thai condiment and this particular set is 
used for noodle dishes but in reality you

can use it on whatever you want but if you go 
to a restaurant and order noodles they'll most
likely give you one of these it's called kreung prung which is a word that means condiment any

kind of condiment we use the same word there are 
traditionally there are four of them there's a

salty sweet sour and spicy it's what I call 
the four essence of flavors so let's take a

look at what each of those ones are so that you 
can also have one of these sitting at your table

so the first one we've got the salty this is 
called premium black premix chili and numba

means fish sauce and really that's all there is 
chopped up Thai chili it's a fish sauce but you

can get a little bit fancier and add some lime 
which is what I get here and sliced lime and

you let it infuse for about 15 minutes with the 
flavors kind of mingle some people get a little

fancier and add some chopped garlic to it but 
I usually don't bother with that now the second

one our sour component is pretty no salt prick 
is chili and numb so miss vinegar and that's

basically all this is chili and vinegar now 
we usually use a big Thai chili called prick

Chifa which is this guy here but you can use a 
jalapeno or a serrano or a Fresno chili if you

want so any big chili that's milder than the 
Thai chilies will work and depending on where

you go sometimes you see this guy blended 
and it'll be orange they'll use orange chili

and they'll blend it to a consistency kind of 
like pesto but it's pretty much the same thing

and third our sweet component is just white 
sugar and finally our spicy is chili powder
